title: Alcaraz on Machac loss: 'I felt like I was playing a Top-5 player'
description: Carlos Alcaraz admits to have had no response to the blistering tennis thrown at him Thursday by Tomas Machac, who upset the World No. 2 in the quarter-finals of the Rolex Shanghai Masters. Alcaraz's 12-match winning streak came to an abrupt end in a 7-6(5), 7-5 defeat at the hands of Machac, who claimed his second win over a Top-5 player (Djokovic, Geneva SF). It was a winning streak that included the pair's maiden Lexus ATP Head2Head clash at the Davis Cup last month, in which Machac was forced to retire at one set apiece. As he did when representing Czechia, Machac took the opening set in a tie-break in Shanghai, but the 23-year-old made no mistake of closing it out in straight sets, exuding extreme confidence throughout. Czech this out! ü§Ø Machac downs Alcaraz to reach the semi-finals in Shanghai, where he will face Sinner!@SH_RolexMasters | #RolexShanghaiMasters pic.twitter.com/kabm9UMx6U ‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) October 10, 2024 ‚ÄúI felt like I was playing against a Top-5 player,‚Äù said Alcaraz, who suffered his first defeat since his second-round exit at the US Open. ‚ÄúNot even Top 10, no, Top 5. His level was so high. I thought that he was going to give me an opportunity, a window, but he didn't. ‚ÄúFrom the first game until the last one, his level was so high. His ball speed, it was unbelievable. Honestly, I felt good on the court, I felt the ball really well, I was hitting well, I was moving well. But, at some points, I didn't know what to do.‚Äù Alcaraz showed signs of a second-set fightback after he had retrieved the break back, but Machac kept his foot on the gas to dismantle the Spaniard‚Äôs serve for a second time before serving out the victory with ease. ‚ÄúIt was unbelievable, it was crazy for me,‚Äù added Alcaraz. ‚ÄúHe was pushing me to the limit all the time that I was thinking that I had to put the right ball in the right place all the time. If not, I was going to run everywhere, or he was going to make a winner. So I think that the pressure he put [on] me was the key in the match.‚Äù Alcaraz, who has qualified for the Nitto ATP Finals in Turin, is next scheduled to play the Rolex Paris Masters after slipping to 51-10 on the season. [NEWSLETTER FORM]
excerpt: Carlos Alcaraz claims to have been offered little respite by Tomas Machac, who laid down a statement of intent on Thursday in their quarter-final clash at the Rolex Shanghai Masters.

html:
Match Reaction

Spaniard praises World No. 33 after quarter-final defeat

October 10, 2024

Hector Retamal/Getty Images

Carlos Alcaraz suffered his first defeat in 13 matches at the Rolex Shanghai Masters. By ATP Staff

Carlos Alcaraz admits to have had no response to the blistering tennis thrown at him Thursday by Tomas Machac, who upset the World No. 2 in the quarter-finals of the Rolex Shanghai Masters.

Alcaraz's 12-match winning streak came to an abrupt end in a 7-6(5), 7-5 defeat at the hands of Machac, who claimed his second win over a Top-5 player (Djokovic, Geneva SF). It was a winning streak that included the pair's maiden Lexus ATP Head2Head clash at the Davis Cup last month, in which Machac was forced to retire at one set apiece.

As he did when representing Czechia, Machac took the opening set in a tie-break in Shanghai, but the 23-year-old made no mistake of closing it out in straight sets, exuding extreme confidence throughout.

‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) October 10, 2024

‚ÄúI felt like I was playing against a Top-5 player,‚Äù said Alcaraz, who suffered his first defeat since his second-round exit at the US Open. ‚ÄúNot even Top 10, no, Top 5. His level was so high. I thought that he was going to give me an opportunity, a window, but he didn't.

‚ÄúFrom the first game until the last one, his level was so high. His ball speed, it was unbelievable. Honestly, I felt good on the court, I felt the ball really well, I was hitting well, I was moving well. But, at some points, I didn't know what to do.‚Äù

Alcaraz showed signs of a second-set fightback after he had retrieved the break back, but Machac kept his foot on the gas to dismantle the Spaniard‚Äôs serve for a second time before serving out the victory with ease.

‚ÄúIt was unbelievable, it was crazy for me,‚Äù added Alcaraz. ‚ÄúHe was pushing me to the limit all the time that I was thinking that I had to put the right ball in the right place all the time. If not, I was going to run everywhere, or he was going to make a winner. So I think that the pressure he put [on] me was the key in the match.‚Äù

Alcaraz, who has qualified for the Nitto ATP Finals in Turin, is next scheduled to play the Rolex Paris Masters after slipping to 51-10 on the season.
